I would like to inform you of my disagreement with Austin. See, I don't think words alone can cause anything to happen or change. If a president declares war, there really is no war without any battling taking place. If a priest declares two people as "husband and wife", it changes nothing unless they actually do something about it. In both of these examples there theoretically is a difference made by words, but no actual change will ever happen by words alone. This being said, words often cause some sort of reaction in the person/people hearing them, but it has nothing to do with if they decide to do something about it or not, since the difference caused this way will be caused by the actual actions taking place. I have been pretty pleased with the Crash Course courses I have watched, but I’m very disappointed in this episode because, as it is a course on philosophy, I was surprised that it unreflectively assumed the current American legal definition of marriage, without any discussion. I understand that the Thought Bubble’s topic is philosophy of language, and discusses the power of speech acts (a beautiful and fascinating subject), and not marriage per se.
Yet why make the assumptions? Why is it assumed impossible to marry someone who is already married or to marry an animal? And why is it assumed possible to marry someone of the same sex?
By presenting these assumptions as settled, the history of the philosophical understandings of marriage are summarily dismissed, from marriage in the Law Code of Hammurapi to defenders of the practice of polygamy to the Christian philosophy of marriage (which I believe to be true). It could easily have been avoided by saying that the speaking of an oath in marriage makes oneself a spouse to another, and then left everything else out, thus leaving the discussion of the philosophy of marriage for another video.

P.S. The speech act that makes people married is not the officiant saying “I pronounce you husband and wife,” but those who speak the vows. The officiant is a legal witness, but has no power to pronounce people married if they haven’t made their vows/promises.

I kind of expected a mention of autism in this episode. Personally I have a lot of trouble with the "quantity" and "relation" maxims (and the "be brief" part of the manner maxim). AKA: I tend to ramble on and on about random things and tell stories with a very high level of detail when it isn't really needed. Other autistic people have a lot of trouble with idioms.

5:38 Obviously, us autistic people are trying our best to communicate (unless there is intentional maxim flouting, which I do sometimes) but the difference is that these rules just don't come naturally to us, and have to be learned and thought about frequently. Not EVERYONE understands these unspoken rules.

This leads to a lot of miscommunication on both sides, for example if a non-autistic person flouts a maxim subtly and the autistic person doesn't understand it, or if an autistic person naturally tends to use $10 words and the non-autistic person thinks they are doing it for a purposeful reason (like to make fun of them).

Philosophers make much ado about "speech acts," but really all speech is an act. Communication is something we do to each other. Communication is fundamentally interaction; transference of information is just a particularly significant part of HUMAN communication. Performative utterances aren't the only things we say that are by their nature interactive. There is also forms of directive modality which direct someone to do something, and discourse particles (like "like," "well," "um," and "you know") which have no real semantic meaning at all but have a pragmatic role in conversation. And even a lot of declarative and interrogative sentences we make are not necessarily about exchanging the information itself as forming (or breaking) bonds with other people, or interacting in other ways. Most of the talk people do in a day is just gossip.

I do not understand why people get so upset over the use of "literally." This is a linguistic device that has been accepted for centuries known as overstatement (or exaggeration). One emphasizes a point by overstating the matter of fact related to the point. This specific use ("literally") has been in use for at least two centuries. Such linguistic devices are as acceptable as metaphors are.

Hi, actual linguist here. I heavily object to the first minute of this video. "literally" is an intensifier, and it has been used as such since 1769:

1769 F. Brooke Hist. Emily Montague IV. ccxvii. 83 "He is a fortunate man to be introduced to such a party of fine women at his arrival; it is literally to feed among the lilies."

If you are going to complain about "literally", you better also be complaining about "really", "real", "very", "truly", "awful", "awful", "extremely", "insanely", "totally", "completely", "utterly", and "absolutely".

I'm so happy someone finally talked about Grove!!!!!! I noticed Hank neglected to suggest reading in this area. an oversight, I'm sure.
(He also presumed the saying/meaning distinction, but we can talk about that later.)
Grice's posthumously printed collection 'Studies in the Ways of Words' is beyond excellent. sometimes I read it just as a pick me up. Grice's style can be difficult, but is penetrable with thought (and conversation) and effortlessly charming.
For more on the particulars of this video you want to read Part 1, Chapter 1: 'Logic and Conversation'.
My personal favourite essays are 'Meaning' and 'Meaning Revisited'.
There's so much more to do with and talk about Grice and Studies (his disdain for the 'A-Philosophers' introduced in this video, the potential for 'be relevant', for example) but this is long enough already. please feel free to discuss studies and ask for more recs in replies to this.

sincerely,
an enthused doctoral student.
